DOCNAME: CASE OF PLAKHTEYEV AND PLAKHTEYEVA v. UKRAINE
CONCLUSION: Preliminary objection joined to merits and dismissed (non-exhaustion of domestic remedies);Remainder inadmissible;Violation of Art. 6-1;Violation of P1-1;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - award
JUDGES: Karel Jungwiert;Mark Villiger;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska;Peer Lorenzen;Rait Maruste;Stanislav Shevchuk;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants were born in DATE and DATE respectively and live in GPE , the GPE region . The first applicant is a farmer who specialises in arable crops . The second applicant is his mother , a pensioner .

CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant was stopped by tax police officers when driving a lorry leased from his mother . On checking the lorry the officers discovered QUANTITY of wheat , QUANTITY of flour and QUANTITY of wheat middlings for which the applicant had no proper documents . The police officers drew up a report on an administrative offence and seized the lorry and the load pending adjudication of the case by the court .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( the “ ORG ” ) found that the first applicant had transported the property of a third person for sale without a relevant business permit and was therefore guilty of unlawful business activity ( an administrative offence ) . ORG fined the applicant CARDINAL NORP hryvnias ( ORG ) and ordered the confiscation of the flour and wheat middlings . It further held that the QUANTITY of wheat were not subject to forfeiture as they belonged to the first applicant .

CARDINAL . According to the applicants , after the judgment of CARDINAL DATE they applied on several occasions to ORG ( ORG ” ) , requesting that the lorry and the wheat load , which were not covered by the confiscation order , be returned to them . Their requests were rejected however .
CARDINAL . On an unspecified date the confiscated products were sold and the funds were transferred to the ORG budget .

CARDINAL . On DATE the President of ORG ( subsequently renamed as ORG ) , following an extraordinary review , quashed the judgment of DATE , stating that the conviction of the first applicant and the imposed penalties had been unsubstantiated . He therefore closed the case .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG returned the lorry and the wheat load to the applicants . According to the applicants the wheat load had deteriorated significantly and the lorry was damaged when returned .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants lodged a claim with ORG against ORG and ORG seeking damages for the wrongful conviction ; for the groundless seizure and lengthy detention of their property ; and for the deterioration of their property when in charge of ORG . They claimed in particular that ORG unlawfully retained the lorry and the wheat load despite the fact that those objects were not covered by the confiscation order ; and that the lorry and the wheat load had significantly deteriorated when returned .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG declared the claim inadmissible , stating , in particular :

“ According to LAW , compensation for pecuniary and non - pecuniary damage caused in the course of the administration of justice can be paid by the ORG to a person who has been groundlessly sentenced provided that the judgment in a criminal case has been quashed as unfair .
However , even in such a case the damage is compensated by the ORG , and not by a court or a judge .

Therefore , the court ( or judge ) as a body ( or individual ) administering justice can not be a defendant in civil litigation , as the law provides another mechanism for correcting mistakes and irregularities committed in the course of the administration of justice . ”
The court did not give any reasons why the part of the applicants’ claim submitted against ORG could not be considered by the court .

CARDINAL . By a letter of DATE the Deputy Chairman of ORG confirmed to the first applicant that he could claim compensation for damage , allegedly inflicted by ORG , by filing a relevant civil suit with a court .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date ORG , having made an internal inquiry , established that ORG had failed to take the necessary steps to return to the owners the lorry and the wheat load in time . It further concluded that disciplinary measures were needless since the relevant official had retired .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants lodged with ORG a cassation appeal against the decision of DATE , contending that the refusal to consider their claim against ORG and ORG had been unlawful .
CARDINAL . On DATE , following their request of CARDINAL DATE , ORG reimbursed to the applicants the value of the confiscated products .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the ORG cassation appeal against the decision of DATE , finding that there had been no procedural irregularities . The applicants were not present at the hearing . By a letter of DATE ORG informed the applicants of that decision .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the LAW provides , inter alia , that everyone is guaranteed the right to challenge in court the decisions , actions or omissions of bodies of ORG power , bodies of local self - government , officials and officers .

CARDINAL . Section QUANTITY of the LAW provides that everyone has the right to receive compensation from the ORG or municipal authorities for pecuniary and non - pecuniary damage incurred as a result of the unlawful actions or omissions of ORG bodies , municipal authorities or their officials in the course of the exercise of their powers .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the LAW concerns the presumption of innocence and provides , inter alia , that if the sentence in a criminal case is quashed as unfair the ORG must provide compensation for any pecuniary and non - pecuniary damage resulting from the groundless conviction .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the Code provided that compensation was to be paid for damage caused by the acts of ORG entities and public officials in the course of the exercise of their administrative powers in accordance with the general rules , unless the law provided otherwise .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the Code provided , inter alia , that objects and documents used to commit an administrative offence could be seized by the competent authorities pending adjudication of the administrative case . Depending on the outcome of the administrative proceedings the seized objects and documents were thereafter to be either confiscated , destroyed , or returned to the relevant persons .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the Code provided that a decision imposing an administrative penalty could be appealed , except for decisions given by the first - instance court . The latter were final and were not subject to the ordinary administrative appeal procedure , unless the legislation provided otherwise .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the Act provided , inter alia , that court judgments in administrative cases were to be enforced by ORG as regards pecuniary penalties .
